- Cost: $20
- Format: In-person and virtual attendance options available (in-person includes lunch)

Presentations will cover topics such as:
- The MRTN calculator for nitrogen management and crop production
- In-season mineralization of cover crop residue in sugar beet
- Precision irrigation and nitrogen management
- Predicting in-season fertilizer needs after fall-applied manure
- Biologicals for smarter nutrient management
- The role of soil organic matter in agricultural nitrogen sustainability
- Lessons from the 2025 growing season (farmer panel)
- Nitrates in water issues and the Minnesota nutrient reduction strategy
- Evaluating nitrogen inhibitors

Certified Crop Advisers can earn continuing education credits by attending the conference. Farmers are encouraged to register and attend either in-person or virtually.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Vincent Medina and Louis Trevino, both members of the Ohlone community, are working to revive Ohlone food traditions and share their culture. 
- They have established a farm and food business called Cafe Ohlone to showcase traditional Ohlone cuisine and ingredients.
- The Ohlone people were nearly wiped out by Spanish colonization and later policies, losing much of their cultural knowledge and practices.
- Medina and Trevino are working to reconnect their community with traditional foods, plants, and stories, as a way to heal from this history of oppression.
- Their work includes hosting educational events, teaching traditional cooking methods, and growing indigenous crops like acorns and wild greens.
- The goal is to not only preserve Ohlone culture, but also empower the community and share their vibrant heritage with the broader public.

items.title: Ag groups urge U.S., Mexico and Canada leaders to move forward with USMCA
items.description: The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA released the results of an economic analysis that shows significant growth in the value of U.S. ag exports to Canada and Mexico since USMCA was enacted.
items.summary:
S., Canada, and Mexico to renew and strengthen the USMCA trade agreement. 

Key statistics:
- U.S. agricultural exports to Canada and Mexico have increased by $20 billion, reaching $60 billion in 2024, along with $1.2 billion in seafood exports - a 47% growth compared to 18% growth in exports to the rest of the world.
- The USMCA has generated $149 billion in total economic contribution to the U.S. economy, supported nearly 500,000 jobs, and $36 billion in wages. For every $1 in ag exports under USMCA, another $2.45 of economic activity was supported.
- The USMCA has contributed $3.6 billion in dairy exports in 2024, making up 44% of all dairy exports. It has also led to $2.81 billion in fresh fruit exports and $2.5 billion in fresh vegetable exports to Canada and Mexico.

The coalition says the USMCA agreement has been positive for U.S. agriculture, but there are some issues that need to be addressed, such as Canada's management of dairy tariff-rate quotas and Mexico's implementation of commitments on common cheese names. They also want more clarity on biotech rules and increased ethanol access in Mexico.

The coalition warns that if the USMCA is not renewed, it would create greater instability and challenges for the already tough farm economy.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist, was interviewed on the Minnesota CropCast podcast (Episode #56) on February 10, 2026.

- Dr. Cates leads the MN Office for Soil Health (MOSH), which works with farmers and conservation professionals to improve soil health across Minnesota.

- MOSH partners with the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR) to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs).

- The podcast discusses farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops, as well as an upcoming intensive educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy.

- Dr. Cates has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and her work aims to turn soil health research into on-the-ground conservation.

- The Minnesota CropCast podcast is hosted by David Nicolai, a crops Extension educator, and Seth Naeve, the Extension soybean agronomist, and covers progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary:
The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) is returning on March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program costs $60 and includes breakfast and lunch. It will cover topics such as irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. 

Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement after attending the program and adopting a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on-farm.

The program is organized by the University of Minnesota to help irrigators and irrigation professionals match irrigation to crop water use, improve water-use efficiency, and reduce water costs. This is particularly important in Minnesota's central region, which has sandy soils and limited precipitation, making irrigation a key component of production agriculture.

Interested participants can register for the event at z.umn.edu/MIP2026. The in-person event will be held at the Cactus Event Center: 43521 Fort Thunder Rd, Perham, MN 56573.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Pollinators like bees play a critical role in food production, with over 80% of the world's flowering plants needing a pollinator to reproduce.

- There are around 525 bee species in Minnesota, with many being ground-nesting and solitary species, not just honey bees.

- Bee populations are declining due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease. The rusty patch bumblebee is now endangered.

- Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is important. Research shows that even small, less expensive habitat plantings can support a variety of bee species.

- Habitat diversity and floral resources are key - the number of different flower species is more important than the surrounding landscape.

- Pollinator habitat doesn't have to be large or highly diverse to be effective. Smaller, less expensive plantings can provide good results.

- Pollinator habitat next to soybean fields did not increase pest issues, and can boost soybean yields up to 20% through improved pollination.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. It will feature new research results and emerging management insights on soybean gall midge (SGM) from Extension entomologists and their graduate students at three Midwestern universities.

The webinar will cover a range of topics, including:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, such as cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) continuing education units (CEUs) by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. The registration process involves receiving a confirmation email and reminder emails with a webinar link.

For more information, visit the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update webpage.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- February is a good time to start vegetable seeds indoors, especially for crops that take a long time to mature.
- Recommended vegetables to start from seed in February include slow-growing herbs like basil and rosemary, tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (broccoli, cauliflower), lettuce, carrots, parsnips, and alliums (onions, leeks).
- For cold climates, seeds can be started indoors in a controlled environment like a greenhouse, cold frame, or low/high tunnel to take advantage of stored thermal energy.
- Tomatoes and peppers need a heat mat to germinate, while lettuce and brassicas can be direct-sown outdoors with protection. Carrots and parsnips require direct sowing in their final location.
- Onions and leeks should be started in February to allow time for maturation before transplanting.
- Farmers in warm climates near the equator may not need as much protection, but still need to watch for persistent pests.
- Faster-growing Asian brassica varieties and rapini/broccolini types can work well for shorter seasons.
- Lettuce and leafy brassicas can provide quick harvests of baby greens, while heading brassicas and tomatoes take longer to mature.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this past week were 8-18 degrees below average, with lows reaching 7 below zero in some areas. January as a whole was about 2 degrees below normal statewide. Precipitation was very low, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended about 2 inches drier than normal. The snow that did fall provided little drought relief, as the light, powdery snow yielded less than 1 inch of liquid water.

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to climb into the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain low, under 0.1 inches. The third week of February is forecasted to be warmer and wetter than average.

The article also discusses the importance of using the N-Rate Calculator and the Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields. Experts John Jones, Gary Schnitkey, and Laura Gentry recommend these tools to help farmers optimize nitrogen applications and protect local watersheds.

Finally, the article mentions the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report radio programs available through the University of Illinois.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

- Click-through rate is no longer the best metric for digital advertising performance in agriculture. The true indicator is now attention time - how long users spend meaningfully engaged with content.

- AgWeb's recent redesign was focused on increasing user attention and engagement. Layout changes reduced distractions and encouraged deeper article reading.

- The data shows clear improvements: 54% more readers reached 75% of articles, 21% more reached 90%. Mobile users also viewed more articles per visit, up 33%.

- Most users (79%) scan content rather than reading word-for-word. Only 16% read every word, absorbing at most 28% of page text.

- Attention time is a better metric than click-through rate, as it measures real impact - whether users stayed, scrolled, and consumed multiple articles.

- The AgWeb redesign provides a template for increasing engagement and attention. This creates more valuable, higher quality impressions for advertisers.

- For ag marketers, the goal should be reaching farmers in focused, engaged moments. AgWeb's optimization for attention offers one of the most effective digital environments.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The goal was to see if growers can maintain productivity and profitability while using reduced tillage and cover crops to protect soil.

The study tested 4 management systems: conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early soybean biomass by ~12% at the V4 stage, but these differences did not persist to R2 growth stage.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across locations, with no significant yield differences between tillage/cover crop systems. 
- Partial net return was highest for NT, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest net return due to higher cover crop costs, though this can be offset by cost-share programs.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term responses as the soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics change under the conservation systems.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key points:
- February is a good time to start late spring transplants and grow quick-maturing crops for early spring markets in greenhouses.
- Not all greenhouses are created equal - they vary from simple plastic structures to fortified designer greenhouses with climate control systems.
- Recommended greenhouse crops for February include:
  - Tomatoes and peppers, which benefit from an early indoor start
  - Brassicas like kale, cabbage, and cauliflower to avoid pests and extreme cold
  - Lettuces, which can be started early indoors 
  - Potatoes, to get full-sized tubers by spring
  - Onions of all kinds
  - Flowers that take a long time to sprout, like lisianthus and dahlias

The article provides details on the different types of greenhouses and their capabilities in terms of temperature increases (30¬∞F for modular plastic, 5-15¬∞F for cold frames, etc.). It emphasizes the importance of understanding your greenhouse type when deciding what to grow.

No specific dates, prices, or expert quotes are mentioned. The article is focused on providing comprehensive guidance to farmers on maximizing their greenhouse growing during the winter months.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should be based on offering farmers something they genuinely need, not just what the business wants to collect.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose shape the quality and purchase-readiness of the leads captured, not just the quantity.
- Shifting the mindset from what the business wants to what farmers need is crucial for designing the right offer that will resonate.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, statistics, dates, names, or locations. It is focused on providing general advice about lead generation strategy for agricultural businesses.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…

Temperatures this week were 4-8 degrees below normal, with lows dipping into the single digits or below zero, and wind chills reaching -20 in some areas. The state also experienced a mostly dry week, with less than half an inch of precipitation in many regions so far in January.

However, a strong winter storm is forecasted to bring significant snowfall, with 3-4 inches expected in central Illinois and 8-12 inches south of Interstate 64 this weekend.

The article also covers the latest WILLAg.org radio programming, including the Commodity Week panel discussion featuring Chip Nellinger, Brian Stark, and Arlan Suderman, as well as the daily Closing Market Report.

Overall, the key information from the article includes:
- Temperatures 4-8¬∞F below normal, with lows in the single digits and wind chills near -20¬∞F
- Less than 0.5 inches of precipitation in January so far, making it one of the driest starts to the year
- Continued cold temperatures expected for at least another week, with potential for 8-12 inches of snow in southern Illinois this weekend
- WILLAg.org radio programs covering commodity markets and closing prices

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Traditional SEO (search engine optimization) focused on winning clicks, but the focus has now moved to winning brand authority and trust through modern AEO (answer engine optimization). 

Farmers are increasingly turning to AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews for instant answers to their questions, rather than traditional search engines. If brands are not present in these new discovery channels, they risk becoming invisible.

Farm Journal, the article's source, is observing this shift in real-time and advising that ag marketers need to reevaluate their strategies for 2026. Key recommendations include:
- Adopting an answer-driven content strategy
- Amplifying trusted voices
- Ensuring brand expertise, content, and authority are discoverable across all channels where farmers are searching, including search engines, AI platforms, voice search, and social media.

Discoverability is now about winning citations, brand mentions, and trusted source references, rather than just clicks. This will be critical for building brand authority even in "zero-click" moments.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Forest farming, also known as multi-story cropping or agroforestry, is the practice of farming within forested land. It integrates small-scale farming with conventional forestry.

- Originating in Brazil's tropical rainforests, forest farming can be beneficial for farmers with forest land, allowing them to diversify their products and have a self-sustaining system.

- Common forest farming methods include thinning forests to allow understory crops, silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching), and alley cropping (growing specialty crops between tree rows).

- Benefits include improved water and soil quality, carbon sequestration, hosting of beneficial organisms, and opportunities to grow specialty crops like mushrooms, ramps, and edible roots.

- Land suited for forest farming includes existing forested areas, riparian areas with trees, and previously cleared land for reforestation.

- Considerations include inventorying natural resources, developing a forest management plan, understanding local markets, and being aware of regulations around wild plant harvesting.

- Experts recommend consulting local agricultural extension offices, state agriculture/forestry agencies, and trusted market contacts to plan and implement a successful forest farming operation.

items.title: Jan 16 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: The second week of the year brought a fleeting taste of spring, with average temperatures between the mid-30s to upper 40s; 8 to 12 degrees above normal. Some of the more impressive daytime high temperatures this week included 69 in Kaskaskia and 68 in Carbondale. January to date has been 7 to 12 degrees above normal statewide, and has been a top 10 warmest first half of January on record in most parts of the state.…
items.summary:
The second week of the year saw above-normal temperatures, with average temps 8-12¬∞F above normal. Some areas reached highs of 69¬∞F in Kaskaskia and 68¬∞F in Carbondale. January so far has been a top 10 warmest first half on record in most of Illinois.

Precipitation has been scarce, with 7-day totals ranging from 0.1 inches in southeast Illinois to 0.75 inches in central Illinois. January to date is 0.5-1 inch drier than normal across the state, except for 1-3 inches of rain in a narrow area between Peoria and Chicago. This winter season has been slightly wetter than normal in northeast Illinois, slightly drier than normal in central/west Illinois, and much drier (top 5 driest on record) in southern Illinois.

The mild weather will end this weekend as much colder air moves in, with highs struggling to reach 20¬∞F in northern Illinois and just above freezing in the south. Little precipitation is expected, mostly light snow. Colder than normal temperatures are forecast for the next 2-3 weeks.

The article also mentions the weekly Commodity Week radio program and Closing Market Report, which provide market analysis and updates.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

1. Spray drones are being increasingly evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. They can provide flexibility, reduce field traffic, and improve access to difficult areas.

2. Adopting spray drone technology requires considering regulations, training, insurance, and management practices. Farmers need to be aware of FAA Part 107 and Part 137 certifications, IDALS licensing, and pesticide label compliance.

3. Insurance coverage specific to agricultural drone operations is recommended, including chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage coverage.

4. When selecting spray drones, key considerations include tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, GPS guidance, and local support availability.

5. Proper training is essential for effective and safe operation, including flight experience, calibration, weather monitoring, and routine maintenance.

6. Farmers are encouraged to start on a limited scale, comparing application results with conventional methods and developing efficient procedures.

7. Several Iowa-based resources are available to support farmers, including Iowa State University programs, the Digital Agriculture Innovation Lab, licensed equipment dealers, and IDALS.

8. Ongoing technological improvements in payload capacity, automation, and data integration will shape the long-term role of spray drones in Iowa crop production.

Key Numbers/Statistics:
- FAA Part 107 remote pilot certification training workshop scheduled on February 24-25, 2026 in Ames, IA.
- Specific insurance coverage requirements for chemical liability and Part 137 certification.

Locations:
- Ames, IA
- Iowa

Experts/Organizations:
- Doug Houser, Digital Agriculture Extension Specialist, Iowa State University
- Iowa State University Extension and Outreach
- Digital Agriculture Innovation Lab
- Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS)
- Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This protects seedlings and results in hardier transplants that mature sooner. The top vegetables to winter sow include cabbages, spinach, onions, and leafy greens like kale and chard. Recommended flowers include pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa. These plants can handle cold weather and many require cold stratification to break dormancy. 

For cabbages, farmers can choose standard varieties or shorter-maturing 'Carex' cabbages. Spinach varieties like 'Avon' and 'Space' are mildew-resistant. Onions require consideration of day length, with long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day varieties suited to different latitude ranges. Leafy greens like kale, chard, and microgreens are easy to grow and nutritious.

Perennial flowers like pansies, echinacea, and larkspur provide natural pest control and can be sold as cut flowers or bedding plants. Snapdragons prefer cool weather and come in different groups suited to varying light and heat conditions. Scabiosa, or pincushion flowers, also attract beneficial insects.

Winter sowing reduces risks compared to direct sowing and allows for earlier maturation, giving farmers an advantage in the spring growing season. Careful selection of cold-hardy plants is key to a successful winter sowing program.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Plant prairie strips: Dedicating 10-25% of farmland to prairie strips can boost yields, add soil nutrients, and attract beneficial insects and predators that help control pests. The diverse plantings support biodiversity above and below ground.

2. Reduce tilling: Minimizing tillage and using cover crops instead can improve soil structure and increase the diversity of insect populations on the land.

3. Practice regenerative grazing: Using rotational grazing models and planting native grasses/forbs instead of non-native forage can improve the health of both the land and livestock, while supporting local ecosystems. Silvopasture with native trees provides habitat and shelter.

4. Implement Integrated Pest Management (IPM): Diversifying plantings and using cultural pest control methods instead of relying on pesticides can attract beneficial insects to naturally manage pests.

5. Establish conservation easements: Partnering with land trusts to place farmland under conservation easements can protect natural resources and habitats, while also providing tax benefits for landowners.

The article states that these strategies are worthwhile investments, as they can boost productivity, reduce input costs, and maintain the health of the surrounding ecosystem that farms rely on. Experts recommend them as effective ways for farmers to support biodiversity and prevent species loss on their land.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. These meetings, organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach, will provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

Key details:
- Dates and locations: January 6 - Sioux Center, January 7 - Storm Lake, January 8 - Burlington, January 9 - Mason City, January 13 - Estherville, January 15 - Waterloo, January 16 - Davenport, January 21 - Ankeny, January 22 - Atlantic, January 27 - Iowa City, January 28 - Le Mars, January 29 - Carroll
- Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, late/on-site registration is $100
- Registration includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources
- Private pesticide applicator recertification will be available for a separate $30 fee
- Topics will include crop market and climate outlooks, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, robots and drones, and more

According to Josh Michel, field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach, "Our goal is always to prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers."

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
S.

The three finalists are:
- Alsum Farms in Friesland, Wisconsin - a multigenerational, vertically integrated potato, pumpkin, and forage operation on over 3,600 acres.
- Dalton Farms in Wakeman, Ohio - a 7th-generation family farm with 2,000 acres of corn and soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and a growing on-farm market.

The article also announces the winners of the 2026 Next Generation Award (Tim Nuss, California) and the 2026 Women in Agriculture Award (Helle Ruddenklau, Oregon). 

The awards will be presented at the 2026 Top Producer Summit on February 9-11 in Nashville, Tennessee. The event is agriculture's premier conference for elite farmers and ranchers, and is sponsored by BASF, Fendt, and Pro Farmer.

The awards celebrate operations demonstrating resilience, innovation, and a focus on the future of agriculture through strong family leadership, diversification, technology adoption, and a commitment to excellence.

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop compared to corn. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant, has lower nitrogen requirements, and is not a host for the tar spot pathogen. Experts will discuss sorghum's production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Attendees will learn about forage sorghum research from Mitch Tuinstra, the Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue. He will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.

Other speakers include Brad Shelton, FPAC superintendent; Jason Tower, Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent; Nick Minton, Purdue Extension beef systems specialist; and Jeff Jackson, Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist.

Venue tours will be available from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm. Dinner and a bull test station tour will be offered from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024 despite concerns about financial performance and lower crop/livestock prices.
- The Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.
- High input costs remained the biggest concern for 34% of farmers, while 29% cited the risk of lower crop/livestock prices, up from 25% in June.
- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points to 81, 6 points lower than July 2023, due to concerns about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.
- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as fewer producers believe it's a bad time for large investments.
- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.
- 72% of crop farmers expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same in 2025, with the remaining respondents divided on expecting increases or decreases.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn:

- Tar spot, a fungal disease, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada. It has also affected crops in 15 other countries in Central and South America, the Caribbean, and U.S. territories.

- Researchers are using a mix of methods including statistics, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision to better understand the dynamics of tar spot. This work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

- The research team has developed a digital method called SCDA (stromata contouring detection algorithm) to quantify tar spot in corn, which they have tested against human raters with promising results. They are refining the training methods to improve the model's accuracy.

- Another collaboration between agricultural and engineering researchers aims to detect and classify disease symptoms in wheat and corn using AI and computer vision approaches. They are integrating drone imagery and weather data to understand the tar spot pathosystem.

- Graduate students are also using disease observations and drone-based imagery to characterize tar spot epidemiological dynamics at various scales and model the disease severity.

- The interdisciplinary nature of the research requires the team to overcome challenges in understanding each other's specialized languages, but it also leads to better problem-solving.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is hosting various sheep-themed competitions, vendors, and educational opportunities at the 2024 Indiana State Fair:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering Indiana-grown wool items, livestock- and country-themed clothing, jewelry, and gifts.
- On August 2 at 10 a.m., there will be an open wool judging and wool sale in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place on August 4 at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held on August 4 at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- From August 8-11 from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., the Taste from Indiana Farms event in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion will offer free samples of Indiana lamb.
- The Sheep to Shawl competition will be held on August 18 at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- Sheep can be found in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion from August 4-20 for open and 4-H shows.

The Indiana Sheep Association is one of the oldest livestock organizations in Indiana, founded in 1876 as the Indiana Wool Growers Association. The Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program was created to support educational, promotional, and research efforts involving sheep in Indiana, funded by a 0.5% checkoff on the net market price of each sheep sold.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- The Purdue Extension Building will feature activities for all ages aligned with the fair's theme "The Art & Nature of Fun," including a Block Party, Book Party, Captain Cash, and exhibits on entomology, human health, forestry, animal sciences, and more.
- The Food Science Department will host "What's Growing on My Spinach?" to explore food microbiology and offer samples of "Cricket Rice Krispies Treats" and Boilermaker Hot Sauce.
- Seed art showcasing the fair's theme will be displayed in livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building.
- Pioneer Village, sponsored by the Purdue Ag Alumni Association, will transport fairgoers to the 1800s with antique tractors, a farm toy show, fiddler's contest, and more.
- Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, including the 4-H Exhibit Hall, Indiana Farmers Coliseum, and Purdue Extension Building.
- Purdue University is a leading public research institution, with over 105,000 students studying across various modalities and locations.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts and recommendations for specific situations. The publication is available for download only and was released on June 12, 2024, through the Wisconsin Crop Manager (WCM) newsletter.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
The key points from the Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update article are:

- Wisconsin winter wheat is 10-14 days ahead of typical growth stages due to the warm spring and timely rain.
- There is a high likelihood of stripe rust appearing in Wisconsin this season, though it has not been detected yet. Farmers are advised to scout for the disease and report any findings.
- Fusarium head blight (FHB) is likely to be an issue this season due to moderate temperatures and adequate precipitation, after recent hot and dry spring seasons.
- FHB can limit wheat yields and produce the mycotoxin deoxynivalenol (DON or vomitoxin), which can lead to grain discounts or rejection if levels exceed 2 ppm.
- Farmers are encouraged to manage for FHB to mitigate these risks.

The article was written on May 20, 2024 by Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, and Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
The main points are:

- Soybean plants can compensate for low plant stands by developing more axillary branches and pods.
- Action should be considered if the stand has fewer than 50,000-60,000 evenly-distributed plants per acre in southern regions, or 75,000 plants per acre in northern regions, or if there are areas larger than 6-10 square feet without any plants.
- Factors to evaluate include the existing plant stand and distribution, calendar date and impact on maturity, weed management, seed/variety availability, cost, and trade-offs between suboptimal stand vs. yield penalty from delayed replanting.
- The article provides a link to a more detailed fact sheet on soybean replant decisions.

No specific dates, names, or statistics are provided in the article summary. The recommendations are general based on plant stand thresholds and regional differences.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:

- The only 2,4-D formulation labeled for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans is the 2,4-D choline formulation found in Enlist One and Enlist Duo herbicides. 2,4-D ester and amine formulations cannot be used.

- There have been reports of producers, agronomists, and crop advisors considering using the unauthorized ester or amine 2,4-D formulations for postemergence applications, which would be illegal.

- For burndown applications, if using a 2,4-D ester or amine product, there is a 7-day soybean plant back interval when using 0.5 lbs ae/acre. This restriction does not apply when using Enlist One or Enlist Duo.

The article was posted on May 11, 2024 by Daniel H. Smith from the UW-Madison Division of Extension and Rodrigo Werle, a Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison. It was published in the WCM newsletter focused on weeds.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary: The Wisconsin CCA (Certified Crop Advisor) Board election results have been posted. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to serve two, three-year terms on the WI CCA Board. All WI CCAs in good standing are eligible for nomination and can vote in future elections, which will be held again in early 2025. The election process was managed by Daniel H. Smith, the Outreach Program Manager for the Crops and Soils Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension.
